content.description:
Abraham Cresques, Cartographer, Detail of the Mali Empire from the Catalan Atlas “Map of the World,” 1375

From west to east, the map shows the Atlantic Ocean, northwest Africa, the southern tip of the Iberian Peninsula, and the far western Mediterranean Sea.

Throughout the image:

Longitudinal lines crisscross in diagonal patterns.

Text in medieval script describes each major locality of the map.

There are four prominent figures on the map:

A long stone wall is drawn from the coast of northwestern Africa to the interior of the continent.

The wall separates the far northern strip of Africa from the kingdoms to the south.

Small forts, churches, mosques, and flags/banners are also shown near the wall.

A series of tents is shown in the west.

A light-complexioned man is shown in the west riding a camel:

He wears a turban that covers his head and neck and shows only his face.

He wears a robe that covers his entire body, except for his hands and feet.

The man and the camel face east.

Mansa Musa is shown in the east:

He is a dark-complexioned man holding a gold scepter in his left hand and a large gold coin in his right hand.

He sits on a throne and wears a large gold crown and a robe.
Photo by Art Images via Getty Images
content.question: Which of the following best explains the importance of griots to the Mali Empire?

choices.label: They traded with merchants in Timbuktu for manufactured goods, which increased the wealth of the Mali Empire.
They served as jurists in the imperial courts of the Mali Empire, which helped to develop a more sophisticated legal system.
They served as generals in the army of the Mali Empire and were immortalized in thirteenth-century equestrian figures.
They preserved the history and culture of the Mali Empire, which helped to maintain its traditions through generations.

content.answer: They preserved the history and culture of the Mali Empire, which helped to maintain its traditions through generations.
